canonical_explanation.text: Everything around us that has weight and takes up space is called matter. Matter exists in three states: solid, liquid, and gas. Solids have a definite shape and a definite volume. Examples include books, stones, and chairs. Liquids have a definite volume but no definite shape; they take the shape of their container. Examples include water, milk, and juice. Gases have neither a definite shape nor a definite volume; they fill up the entire space available. Examples include air, steam, and cooking gas. Matter can change from one state to another. Melting is when a solid becomes a liquid (ice to water). Freezing is when a liquid becomes a solid (water to ice). Evaporation is when a liquid becomes a gas (water drying from wet clothes). Condensation is when a gas becomes a liquid (water drops on a cold glass). Materials around us can be natural (wood, cotton, wool, silk) or man-made (plastic, nylon, glass). Materials have different properties: hard or soft, rough or smooth, transparent (clear glass) or opaque (wood). We choose materials based on their properties for different uses.
rules: Matter has weight and takes up space
Solids: definite shape and definite volume
Liquids: no definite shape, definite volume, take container shape
Gases: no definite shape, no definite volume, fill all space
Melting: solid to liquid (ice to water)
Freezing: liquid to solid (water to ice)
Evaporation: liquid to gas (wet clothes drying)
Condensation: gas to liquid (water drops on cold glass)
Natural materials: wood, cotton, wool, silk

questions.question_text: How many states of matter are there?
questions.explanation_correct: There are three states of matter: solid, liquid, and gas. Everything around us exists in one of these three states. Water, for example, can exist as ice (solid), water (liquid), or steam (gas).
questions.explanation_incorrect: At the Class 4 level, we study three states of matter: solid, liquid, and gas. These are the three common forms in which all matter exists around us.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a solid?
questions.explanation_correct: A book is a solid because it has a definite shape and a definite volume. You can pick it up and it does not change shape or flow like a liquid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milk and juice are liquids that flow and take the shape of their container. Air is a gas that fills all available space. A book is the only solid in this list with a fixed shape.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a liquid?
questions.explanation_correct: Water is a liquid. It flows, takes the shape of its container, and has a definite volume. You can pour water from a glass into a bottle and it will change shape to fit the new container.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Stone and table are solids with fixed shapes. Oxygen is a gas. Water is the liquid because it flows, has no fixed shape, but has a definite volume.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a gas?
questions.explanation_correct: Air is a gas. It has no definite shape and no definite volume. It fills up all the available space in a room, a balloon, or any container. We cannot see air, but we can feel it when the wind blows.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ice is a solid, oil is a liquid, and sand is a solid (made of tiny solid particles). Air is the gas in this list - it has no fixed shape or volume and fills all available space.

questions.question_text: True or False: Water is a solid because we can see it.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Being able to see something does not make it a solid. Water is a liquid because it flows, takes the shape of its container, and has no definite shape. Many liquids are visible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Visibility does not determine the state of matter. Water is a liquid because it flows and takes the shape of its container, not a solid.

questions.question_text: Which property is TRUE about solids?

options.text: They have a definite shape and definite volume

questions.explanation_correct: Solids have a definite shape (they keep their shape unless broken or cut) and a definite volume (they take up a fixed amount of space). A brick stays brick-shaped no matter where you put it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Flowing easily is a property of liquids. Filling the entire container is a property of gases. Having no definite shape is for liquids and gases. Solids have both definite shape and volume.

questions.question_text: Liquids take the shape of their container. This means liquids have:

options.text: No definite shape but definite volume
No definite shape and no definite volume
A definite shape and no definite volume

questions.explanation_correct: Liquids have no definite shape (they take the shape of whatever container they are in) but have a definite volume (100 mL of water remains 100 mL whether in a glass or a bowl).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Liquids do NOT have a definite shape - they change shape based on their container. But they DO have a definite volume - the amount stays the same regardless of the container shape.

questions.question_text: Which property is TRUE about gases?

options.text: They fill up the entire space available

questions.explanation_correct: Gases fill up the entire space available to them. They have no definite shape and no definite volume. When you open a perfume bottle, the gas spreads throughout the entire room.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gases do not have a fixed shape or fixed volume. They spread out to fill all available space. This is why you can smell cooking from another room - the gas molecules spread everywhere.

questions.question_text: If you pour water from a round glass into a square box, what happens?

options.text: The water takes the shape of the square box

questions.explanation_correct: When you pour water from a round glass into a square box, the water takes the shape of the square box. This is because liquids have no definite shape and always take the shape of their container.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Liquids do not keep their previous shape. They flow and take the shape of whatever container they are poured into. So water from a round glass will become square-shaped in a square box.

questions.question_text: You can smell the agarbatti (incense stick) burning in one corner of the room even if you are in the other corner. This shows that:

options.text: Gases spread out and fill the entire space
Solids can move on their own

questions.explanation_correct: The fragrance of the incense stick reaches you because the gas molecules from the burning stick spread out in all directions and fill the entire room. This is a property of gases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Smoke particles and fragrance molecules are in a gaseous state. They spread throughout the room because gases have no fixed shape or volume and fill all available space.

questions.question_text: A ________ has a definite shape and a definite volume.
questions.explanation_correct: A solid has both a definite shape and a definite volume. Unlike liquids (which change shape) and gases (which have no fixed shape or volume), solids maintain their shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Liquids change shape based on their container. Gases have neither fixed shape nor volume. Only solids have both a definite shape and a definite volume.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the three states of matter?

options.text: Solids flow, liquids are rigid, gases have fixed volume
Solids have fixed shape, liquids take container shape, gases fill all space
Solids fill all space, liquids have fixed shape, gases flow
Solids and liquids are the same, gases are different

questions.explanation_correct: Solids have a fixed shape, liquids take the shape of their container, and gases fill all available space. These are the key properties that distinguish the three states of matter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Solids do not flow (liquids do). Liquids are not rigid (solids are). Gases do not have fixed volume. The correct description is: solids have fixed shape, liquids take container shape, gases fill all space.

questions.question_text: When ice melts, it changes from:
questions.explanation_correct: When ice melts, it changes from solid to liquid. Ice is the solid form of water. When heated, ice absorbs heat and turns into liquid water. This change from solid to liquid is called melting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Melting is always a change from solid to liquid. Ice (solid) becomes water (liquid) when heated. The reverse (liquid to solid) is called freezing.

questions.question_text: When water is cooled and turns into ice, this process is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Freezing is when a liquid turns into a solid by losing heat. When water is put in a freezer, it loses heat and turns into ice. This change from liquid to solid is called freezing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Melting is solid to liquid. Evaporation is liquid to gas. Condensation is gas to liquid. The change from liquid (water) to solid (ice) is called freezing.

questions.question_text: Wet clothes dry in the sun because water changes from liquid to gas. This process is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Evaporation is when a liquid changes into a gas (vapour). The sun's heat causes the water in wet clothes to evaporate and turn into water vapour, which goes into the air. That is why the clothes become dry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Freezing is liquid to solid. Melting is solid to liquid. Condensation is gas to liquid. When water turns into gas (vapour), the process is evaporation.

questions.question_text: Water drops form on the outside of a cold glass of water. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Condensation is when gas (water vapour in the air) changes into liquid. The cold glass cools the air around it, and the water vapour in the air condenses into tiny water droplets on the glass surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaporation is liquid to gas. Melting is solid to liquid. Freezing is liquid to solid. When water vapour in air touches a cold surface and turns into droplets, it is condensation.

questions.question_text: In winter, you can see your breath as a white mist. This happens because:

options.text: Warm water vapour in your breath condenses in the cold air

questions.explanation_correct: When you breathe out, your breath contains warm water vapour. In cold winter air, this water vapour quickly cools and condenses into tiny water droplets, forming the white mist you can see.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Your lungs do not produce smoke and air does not become visible. The white mist is caused by the warm water vapour in your breath condensing into tiny water droplets when it meets the cold air.

questions.question_text: A kulfi (ice cream) left on a plate begins to melt. What change of state is happening?
questions.explanation_correct: Kulfi is a frozen solid. When left on a plate at room temperature, it absorbs heat and begins to melt, changing from solid to liquid. This is the process of melting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kulfi is not already a liquid (so not freezing), not becoming gas (so not evaporation), and is not gas turning to liquid (so not condensation). It is changing from solid to liquid, which is melting.

questions.question_text: True or False: Boiling water on a stove produces steam, which is water in the gas form.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. When water is boiled, it changes from liquid to gas (steam or water vapour). This is evaporation happening very fast due to the high temperature. The steam you see above a boiling pot is water in gas form.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Boiling causes water (liquid) to change into steam (gas). This is the same as evaporation but happens faster because of the high heat from the stove.

questions.question_text:
Match the process with the correct change of state:
1. Melting - (a) Gas to liquid
2. Freezing - (b) Solid to liquid
3. Evaporation - (c) Liquid to solid
4. Condensation - (d) Liquid to gas

Choose the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Melting = solid to liquid (1-b), Freezing = liquid to solid (2-c), Evaporation = liquid to gas (3-d), Condensation = gas to liquid (4-a).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: Melting (solid→liquid), Freezing (liquid→solid), Evaporation (liquid→gas), Condensation (gas→liquid). The correct matching is 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a REVERSIBLE change?
questions.explanation_correct: Melting ice is reversible because you can freeze the water back into ice. Burning paper, cooking an egg, and baking a cake are irreversible changes because you cannot get the original material back.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Burning, cooking, and baking permanently change materials and cannot be undone. Melting ice is reversible because you can freeze the water back to ice, and the cycle can repeat.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a natural material?
questions.explanation_correct: Cotton is a natural material that comes from cotton plants. Natural materials are found in nature and are not made by humans. Other natural materials include wood, wool, silk, and jute.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic, nylon, and glass are all man-made materials created in factories. Cotton is the only natural material in this list, coming directly from cotton plants.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a man-made material?
questions.explanation_correct: Plastic is a man-made material. It does not exist in nature and is manufactured in factories from chemicals. Wood comes from trees, wool from sheep, and silk from silkworms - all natural.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wood, wool, and silk are all found in nature (trees, sheep, and silkworms). Plastic is the man-made material, produced in factories using chemicals.

questions.question_text: A window is made of glass because glass is:
questions.explanation_correct: Glass is used for windows because it is transparent, meaning light can pass through it. This lets sunlight enter rooms while keeping wind and rain out. We can also see through glass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Glass is not soft or very flexible. While it may resist water, the main reason for using glass in windows is that it is transparent - it allows light to pass through.

questions.question_text: Why is a cooking pot made of metal and not plastic?

options.text: Because metal can withstand heat without melting, but plastic would melt
Because metal is lighter than plastic

questions.explanation_correct: Cooking pots are made of metal because metal can withstand high temperatures without melting. Plastic would melt or burn when placed on a flame. Metal is also a good conductor of heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The main reason is heat resistance, not cost or weight. Metal can handle the high heat of cooking, while plastic would melt on a stove. This is why we choose materials based on their properties.

questions.question_text: Raincoats are made of waterproof material like plastic. Why?

options.text: Because plastic does not allow water to pass through

questions.explanation_correct: Raincoats are made of plastic or waterproof material because these materials do not let water pass through them. This keeps the person wearing the raincoat dry during rain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While raincoats may be colourful, the main reason for using plastic is that it is waterproof - water cannot pass through it. Cotton or wool would get wet and heavy in rain.

questions.question_text: True or False: Wood and plastic are both natural materials.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Wood is a natural material that comes from trees, but plastic is a man-made material produced in factories from chemicals. Not all common materials are natural.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Wood is natural (from trees), but plastic is man-made (manufactured in factories). They are in different categories.

questions.question_text: Sugar can be seen, touched, and has weight. Is sugar matter?

options.text: Yes, because it has weight and takes up space
No, because it dissolves in water

questions.explanation_correct: Yes, sugar is matter because it has weight and takes up space. Anything that has weight (mass) and occupies space is called matter. Sugar is a solid form of matter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Being sweet, dissolving in water, or being white does not determine if something is matter. The definition of matter is anything that has weight and takes up space. Sugar has both, so it is matter.

questions.question_text: Which statement about liquids and gases is CORRECT?

options.text: Both liquids and gases have a definite shape
Both liquids and gases have a definite volume
Both liquids and gases have no definite shape
Neither liquids nor gases are matter

questions.explanation_correct: Both liquids and gases have no definite shape - liquids take the shape of their container, and gases fill all available space. However, liquids have a definite volume while gases do not.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Liquids and gases are both matter and both lack a definite shape. The difference is that liquids have a definite volume while gases do not. They share the property of having no fixed shape.

questions.question_text: A glass of water is left on a table for many days. Slowly, the water level drops. What is happening?

options.text: The water is evaporating into the air

questions.explanation_correct: The water is slowly evaporating. Even at room temperature, water molecules at the surface gain enough energy to escape into the air as water vapour. Over many days, the water level drops noticeably.
questions.explanation_incorrect: With no one drinking it and no leak in the glass, the water level drops because of evaporation. Water slowly turns into water vapour and escapes into the air, even without boiling.

questions.question_text: Classify the following: stone, milk, air, chair, juice, steam.

options.text: Solids: stone, chair; Liquids: milk, juice; Gases: air, steam
Solids: stone, milk; Liquids: chair, juice; Gases: air, steam
Solids: stone, chair, air; Liquids: milk, juice; Gases: steam
Solids: stone, chair; Liquids: milk, juice, steam; Gases: air

questions.explanation_correct: Solids (definite shape and volume): stone, chair. Liquids (flow, take container shape): milk, juice. Gases (fill all space): air, steam. Steam is water in gas form, not a liquid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: stone and chair have fixed shapes (solids), milk and juice flow (liquids), air and steam spread out (gases). Steam is water in the gas form, not a liquid.

questions.question_text: A material that lets light pass through it completely is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A transparent material lets light pass through it completely, so you can see through it clearly. Glass, clean water, and air are examples of transparent materials.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Opaque materials block all light (wood, metal). Translucent materials let some light through but not clearly (frosted glass). Transparent materials let all light through clearly.

questions.question_text: Which material would you choose to make an umbrella?
questions.explanation_correct: Waterproof nylon or plastic is the best choice for an umbrella because these materials do not let water pass through. Paper would get wet and tear, cotton cloth would absorb water, and wool would get heavy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Paper tears when wet. Cotton absorbs water. Wool gets heavy in rain. Only waterproof materials like nylon or plastic are suitable for umbrellas because they keep the rain out.

questions.question_text: The change of a liquid into a gas is called ________.
questions.explanation_correct: Evaporation is the change of a liquid into a gas (vapour). When water evaporates, it turns into water vapour. This happens when wet clothes dry, puddles disappear, or water boils.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Freezing is liquid to solid. Melting is solid to liquid. Condensation is gas to liquid. The change from liquid to gas is called evaporation.

questions.question_text: Sand grains are tiny but each grain has a fixed shape. Is sand a solid, liquid, or gas?

options.text: Liquid, because it can be poured
Solid, because each grain has a fixed shape and volume

questions.explanation_correct: Sand is a solid. Even though sand can be poured like a liquid, each individual grain has a definite shape and volume. Sand is made of many tiny solid particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Although sand can be poured, it is not a liquid. Each grain of sand is a tiny solid with its own fixed shape. Sand is a collection of solid particles, making it a solid material.

questions.question_text: Water can exist as ice, liquid water, and steam. What causes water to change between these states?

options.text: Putting water in a different container

questions.explanation_correct: Temperature changes cause water to change state. Cooling water turns it to ice (freezing). Heating ice turns it to water (melting). Heating water further turns it to steam (evaporation/boiling).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Colour, salt, and container changes do not cause changes of state. Temperature is the key factor. Heating causes melting and evaporation, while cooling causes freezing and condensation.

questions.question_text: We cannot see air, but we know it exists. How can we prove that air is matter?

options.text: We can see air when the wind blows
Air fills a balloon and the balloon has weight, showing air takes up space and has weight
We cannot prove air is matter

questions.explanation_correct: When you blow air into a balloon, it takes up space inside the balloon (the balloon gets bigger). A blown balloon weighs more than an empty one, proving air has weight. Since air takes up space and has weight, it is matter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We cannot see air, and it has no colour. But we can prove it is matter by inflating a balloon - the air takes up space (occupies volume) and adds weight, which are the two properties of matter.

questions.question_text: Which pair correctly matches the material with its property?
questions.explanation_correct: Glass is both transparent (light passes through it) and hard (rigid, not soft). This makes it perfect for windows. Rubber is flexible, iron is hard but not soft, and cotton absorbs water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rubber is flexible (not hard). Iron is hard (not soft). Cotton absorbs water (not waterproof). Glass being transparent and hard is the correct pairing of material and its properties.

questions.question_text: True or False: Melting and freezing are reverse processes.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Melting changes a solid to a liquid (ice to water), and freezing changes a liquid to a solid (water to ice). They are exact reverse processes, and the material can keep going back and forth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Melting (solid to liquid) and freezing (liquid to solid) are indeed reverse processes. You can melt ice into water and freeze it back into ice.

questions.question_text: If you pour 500 mL of juice into a 1 litre bottle, how much space does the juice take?

options.text: It fills the whole bottle (1 litre)
It takes only 500 mL of space and the rest is empty

questions.explanation_correct: Juice is a liquid. Liquids have a definite volume, so 500 mL stays 500 mL regardless of the container size. The juice will occupy only half of the 1 litre bottle, and the rest will be filled with air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Liquids have a definite volume. 500 mL of juice stays 500 mL whether in a glass, a bottle, or a bucket. It does not expand to fill the container (that is what gases do) or shrink.

questions.question_text: A material that does not let light pass through is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An opaque material does not let light pass through it. You cannot see through opaque objects. Wood, metal, stone, and cardboard are all opaque materials.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Transparent materials let all light through. Translucent materials let some light through. Shiny describes surface reflection. The term for materials that block all light is opaque.

questions.question_text: In a kitchen, steam rises from a boiling pot and forms water drops on the cool ceiling. Which two processes happen?

options.text: Evaporation (water to steam) and condensation (steam to water drops)

questions.explanation_correct: Two processes happen: First, evaporation (liquid water turns into steam/gas from the boiling pot). Second, condensation (steam hits the cool ceiling and turns back into water drops).
questions.explanation_incorrect: There is no melting or freezing happening here. The boiling water evaporates into steam (liquid to gas), and then the steam condenses on the cool ceiling (gas back to liquid drops).

questions.question_text: The three states of matter are ________, ________, and ________.
questions.explanation_correct: The three states of matter are solid, liquid, and gas. All matter exists in one of these three states. Temperature changes can cause matter to change from one state to another.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hard/soft/flexible are properties of materials, not states. Hot/cold/warm describe temperature. Big/medium/small describe size. The three states of matter are solid, liquid, and gas.

questions.question_text: Why should we reduce the use of plastic?

options.text: Because plastic does not break down easily and pollutes the environment
Because plastic is a natural material

questions.explanation_correct: Plastic does not break down (decompose) easily in nature. It stays in the environment for hundreds of years, polluting soil, water, and harming animals. Using less plastic helps protect our environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic is not expensive or heavy - in fact, it is cheap and light. It is also NOT a natural material. The real problem is that plastic does not decompose and causes serious environmental pollution.

questions.question_text: When you blow air into a balloon, the balloon gets bigger. This proves that:
questions.explanation_correct: When air is blown into a balloon, the balloon expands because the air takes up space inside it. This proves that air (a gas) occupies space, which is one of the properties of matter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Air has no colour and is not a liquid. Air is not heavier than water. The balloon expanding proves that air takes up space, confirming that even invisible gases are matter.

questions.question_text: Dew drops appear on grass early in the morning. Which process causes this?
questions.explanation_correct: Dew drops form by condensation. At night, the temperature drops and the cool grass surface causes water vapour in the air to condense into tiny water droplets. These droplets are dew.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaporation turns liquid to gas. Freezing turns liquid to solid. Melting turns solid to liquid. Dew forms when water vapour in the air condenses into liquid drops on cool surfaces - this is condensation.

questions.question_text: True or False: A gas has a definite volume.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. A gas does NOT have a definite volume. Gases expand to fill whatever space is available. The same amount of gas in a small balloon takes up less space than in a large balloon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Gases have no definite volume - they spread out to fill the entire available space. Only solids and liquids have a definite volume.

questions.question_text: Which material is best for making school furniture?
questions.explanation_correct: Wood or metal is best for school furniture because they are strong, hard, and durable. They can support the weight of students. Rubber is too flexible, glass is fragile, and paper is too weak.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rubber bends too easily. Glass is breakable and dangerous. Paper is not strong enough. Wood and metal are strong, rigid, and long-lasting, making them ideal for furniture.

questions.question_text: The water cycle involves which changes of state?
questions.explanation_correct: The water cycle involves evaporation (water from rivers/oceans becomes vapour), condensation (vapour forms clouds), and sometimes freezing (when rain becomes snow or ice). Water keeps changing state in this cycle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The water cycle involves multiple changes of state: evaporation (liquid to gas), condensation (gas to liquid in clouds), precipitation (rain/snow), and sometimes freezing. Water continuously changes states.

questions.question_text: Which of the following has BOTH no definite shape AND no definite volume?
questions.explanation_correct: Steam (water in gas form) has no definite shape and no definite volume. It spreads to fill whatever space is available. Water and juice are liquids (no shape but fixed volume). Ice is a solid (fixed shape and volume).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ice has both definite shape and volume (solid). Water and juice have definite volume but no definite shape (liquids). Only steam (gas) has neither definite shape nor definite volume.
